title: People are withdrawing their Super to pay for dental work more than ever | ABC NEWS
description: Experts are concerned Australians withdrew more than $817 million from their super for dental last financial year, compared to about $66 million in 2018-19. Some people who have raided their nest eggs for these procedures have been contacting the ABC to share horror stories, while others have said it has been life-changing. title: ABC taken into Gaza area under IDF control for first time since ceasefire | ABC NEWS
description: Israel has escorted a foreign media contingent into Gaza for the first time since the ceasefire with Hamas.  Hours later Israel launched strikes on Gaza City after Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu accused Hamas of violating the ceasefire agreement by attacking a soldier. Israel has also accused Hamas of staging efforts to reclaim the bodies of dead hostages. title: Perry Kouroumblis faces court over 1977 Easey St murders as committal hearing begins | ABC NEWS
description: Perry Kouroumblis, accused of committing Melbourne's gruesome Easey St murders, has appeared in court with a magistrate to decide whether there's enough evidence to take the matter to trial. The prosecution's case relies heavily on DNA evidence collected decades ago at the crime scene. Suzanne Armstrong and Susan Bartlett were stabbed to death in their Collingwood share house in 1977. title: Largest police operation in Rio de Janeiro turns deadly | The World | ABC NEWS
description: At least 64 people have been killed in a police operation targeting criminal networks in Brazil ahead of the United Nation's Climate Summit, COP30. The police raid is the largest and deadliest in Rio de Janeiro's history, with more than 80 arrests made. As Amanda Robson reports, the disruptions have led to many locals worried about the violence. title: Storm chaser flies into the eye of Hurricane Melissa | The World | ABC NEWS
description: Hurricane Melissa is this year's strongest storm and the worst to ever hit Jamaica. The system has also made landfall in Cuba as a category three storm. Meteorologist Matthew Cappucci, who was a passenger on the 'Hurricane Hunter' flight that entered the eye of Melissa, tells The World it was a "sinisterly serene" scene. title: Ancient story that lives at the bottom of the ocean | Deep Time | ABC NEWS
description: At Murujuga in Western Australia’s Pilbara region, people hold a songline connected to land that is now underwater. The rock art all around here is like an encyclopedia into our nation’s deep history, capturing life continuously over 50,000 years, including changes to the landscape. A deeply sacred place that visitors groups would travel to for important ceremony and law, the rock engravings passed down accumulated knowledge from one generation to the next for thousands of years. title: No rate cut until mid-2026, says NAB chief economist | The Business | ABC NEWS
description: Inflation has surged in the September quarter with consumer prices rising at an annual pace of 3.2 per cent, up from 2.1 per cent in the June quarter. The "trimmed mean" for the September quarter, which strips out the most volatile price moves up and down, came in at 1 per cent. The headline number was 1.3 per cent. On an annual basis, the trimmed mean lifted to the top of the RBA's target band at 3 per cent. It was much hotter than the RBA and market economists were expecting, squashing hopes of a rate cut next week. In fact, NAB chief economist Sally Auld told The Business NAB isn't expecting another rate cut until mid-2026. "No rate cuts for the rest of this year, likely no rate cuts in the first quarter of next year, but we do have one more rate cut in our profile but not until May of 2026," She said. "I think really the message from today's numbers is that it is going to require a little bit of patience on the part of mortgage holders just to give the Reserve Bank a good chance to get comfortable and a bit more confident in terms of some of the underlying drivers of inflation."  #ABCBusiness Subscribe: http://ab.co/1svxLVE Read more here: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2025-10-29/september-quarter-inflation-kills-interest-rate-cut/105946770  ABC NEWS provides around the clock coverage of news events as they break in Australia and abroad. title: Albanese attends exclusive dinner with Trump ahead of APEC summit | ABC NEWS
description: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has attended a dinner with a select group of world leaders including US President Donald Trump at the Hilton hotel in South Korea's  ahead of the APEC summit.  Other attendees included Kiwi Prime Minister Christopher Luxon, Thai Prime Minister Anutin Charnvirakul and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney.  The US president is expected to meet Chinese counterpart Xi Jinping on the sidelines of the summit to discuss avoiding hefty tariffs and restrictions on rare earth exports. title: Sarah Ferguson takes on 'testy' Kamala Harris | ABC News Daily podcast
description: Kamala Harris is back on your screens.   The former vice-president is out spruiking her memoir 107 Days, which unpacks her 2024 race for the US presidency, but she’s also testing the waters to see if she could run again.   Today, 7.30 host Sarah Ferguson on her Australian exclusive, and at times testy, interview with the former vice-president.   Featured:    Sarah Ferguson, host of the ABC’s 7.30 program

title: Australian faces lengthy US jail term after selling trade secrets to Russian broker | ABC NEWS
description: An Australian man has pleaded guilty in a Washington DC court to selling cybersecurity information to a Russian broker.  Peter Williams admitted to leaking eight trade secrets from his company, which is a subcontractor for the US Department of Defense, to a company which sells cyber exploit opportunities to the Kremlin.  The 39-year-old former Australian Signals Directorate (ASD) employee is now facing up to 20 years in jail. US Attorney-General Pam Bondi says the case signals that American national security is ‘not for sale’. title: Deadly round of Israeli strikes tests fragile ceasefire in Gaza | ABC NEWS
description: The United States maintains the ceasefire it brokered in Gaza is holding, despite the latest strikes by Israel to thwart what it claims was an imminent attack by Hamas. Gaza's health ministry says more than 100 people were killed in the strikes. Both sides continue to accuse each other of ceasefire violations, with Israel saying Hamas has staged the discovery of human remains in the search for dead hostages.
